Bells\r\n\r\n Epilogue\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBook First\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter I\r\nThe Workshop\r\n\r\n\r\nWith a single drop of ink for a mirror, the Egyptian sorcerer\r\nundertakes to reveal to any chance comer far-reaching visions of the\r\npast. This is what I undertake to do for you, reader. With this drop of\r\nink at the end of my pen, I will show you the roomy workshop of Mr.\r\nJonathan Burge, carpenter and builder, in the village of Hayslope, as\r\nit appeared on the eighteenth of June, in the year of our Lord 1799.\r\n\r\nThe afternoon sun was warm on the five workmen there, busy upon doors\r\nand window-frames and wainscoting. A scent of pine-wood from a tentlike\r\npile of planks outside the open door mingled itself with the scent of\r\nthe elder-bushes which were spreading their summer snow close to the\r\nopen window opposite; the slanting sunbeams shone through the\r\ntransparent shavings that flew before the steady plane, and lit up the\r\nfine grain of the oak panelling which stood propped against the wall.\r\nOn a heap of those soft shavings a rough, grey shepherd dog had made\r\nhimself a pleasant bed, and was lying with his nose between his\r\nfore-paws, occasionally wrinkling his brows to cast a glance at the\r\ntallest of the five workmen, who was carving a shield in the centre of\r\na wooden mantelpiece. It was to this workman that the strong barytone\r\nbelonged which was heard above the sound of plane and hammer singing\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nAwake, my soul, and with the sun\r\nThy daily stage of duty run;\r\nShake off dull sloth...\r\n\r\n\r\nHere some measurement was to be taken which required more concentrated\r\nattention, and the sonorous voice subsided into a low whistle; but it\r\npresently broke out again with renewed vigour\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nLet all thy converse be sincere,\r\nThy conscience as the noonday clear.\r\n\r\n\r\nSuch a voice could only come from a broad chest, and the broad chest\r\nbelonged to a large-boned, muscular man nearly six feet high, with a\r\nback so flat and a head so well poised that when he drew himself up to\r\ntake a more distant survey of his work, he had the air of a soldier\r\nstanding at ease. The sleeve rolled up above the elbow showed an arm\r\nthat was likely to win the prize for feats of strength; yet the long\r\nsupple hand, with its broad finger-tips, looked ready for works of\r\nskill. In his tall stalwartness Adam Bede was a Saxon, and justified\r\nhis name; but the jet-black hair, made the more noticeable by its\r\ncontrast with the light paper cap, and the keen glance of the dark eyes\r\nthat shone from under strongly marked, prominent and mobile eyebrows,\r\nindicated a mixture of Celtic blood. The face was large and roughly\r\nhewn, and when in repose had no other beauty than such as belongs to an\r\nexpression of good-humoured honest intelligence.\r\n\r\nIt is clear at a glance that the next workman is Adam\xe2\x80\x99s brother. He is\r\nnearly as tall; he has the same type of features, the same hue of hair\r\nand complexion; but the strength of the family likeness seems only to\r\nrender more conspicuous the remarkable difference of expression both in\r\nform and face. Seth\xe2\x80\x99s broad shoulders have a slight stoop; his eyes are\r\ngrey; his eyebrows have less prominence and more repose than his\r\nbrother\xe2\x80\x99s; and his glance, instead of being keen, is confiding and\r\nbenign. He has thrown off his paper cap, and you see that his hair is\r\nnot thick and straight, like Adam\xe2\x80\x99s, but thin and wavy, allowing you to\r\ndiscern the exact contour of a coronal arch that predominates very\r\ndecidedly over the brow.\r\n\r\nThe idle tramps always felt sure they could get a copper from Seth;\r\nthey scarcely ever spoke to Adam.\r\n\r\nThe concert of the tools and Adam\xe2\x80\x99s voice was at last broken by Seth,\r\nwho, lifting the door at which he had been working intently, placed it\r\nagainst the wall, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cThere! I\xe2\x80\x99ve finished my door to-day,\r\nanyhow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe workmen all looked up; Jim Salt, a burly, red-haired man known as\r\nSandy Jim, paused from his planing, and Adam said to Seth, with a sharp\r\nglance of surprise, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Dost think thee\xe2\x80\x99st finished the door?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, with answering surprise; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s awanting\r\nto\xe2\x80\x99t?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA loud roar of laughter from the other three workmen made Seth look\r\nround confusedly. Adam did not join in the laughter, but there was a\r\nslight smile on his face as he said, in a gentler tone than before,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, thee\xe2\x80\x99st forgot the panels.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe laughter burst out afresh as Seth clapped his hands to his head,\r\nand coloured over brow and crown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHoorray!\xe2\x80\x9d shouted a small lithe fellow called Wiry Ben, running\r\nforward and seizing the door. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ll hang up th\xe2\x80\x99 door at fur end o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nshop an\xe2\x80\x99 write on\xe2\x80\x99t \xe2\x80\x98Seth Bede, the Methody, his work.\xe2\x80\x99 Here, Jim,\r\nlend\xe2\x80\x99s hould o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 red pot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense!\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam. \xe2\x80\x9cLet it alone, Ben Cranage. You\xe2\x80\x99ll mayhap be\r\nmaking such a slip yourself some day; you\xe2\x80\x99ll laugh o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 other side o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyour mouth then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCatch me at it, Adam. It\xe2\x80\x99ll be a good while afore my head\xe2\x80\x99s full o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nth\xe2\x80\x99 Methodies,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, but it\xe2\x80\x99s often full o\xe2\x80\x99 drink, and that\xe2\x80\x99s worse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen, however, had now got the \xe2\x80\x9cred pot\xe2\x80\x9d in his hand, and was about to\r\nbegin writing his inscription, making, by way of preliminary, an\r\nimaginary S in the air.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it alone, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d Adam called out, laying down his tools,\r\nstriding up to Ben, and seizing his right shoulder. \xe2\x80\x9cLet it alone, or\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll shake the soul out o\xe2\x80\x99 your body.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBen shook in Adam\xe2\x80\x99s iron grasp, but, like a plucky small man as he was,\r\nhe didn\xe2\x80\x99t mean to give in. With his left hand he snatched the brush\r\nfrom his powerless right, and made a movement as if he would perform\r\nthe feat of writing with his left. In a moment Adam turned him round,\r\nseized his other shoulder, and, pushing him along, pinned him against\r\nthe wall. But now Seth spoke.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet be, Addy, let be. Ben will be joking. Why, he\xe2\x80\x99s i\xe2\x80\x99 the right to\r\nlaugh at me\xe2\x80\x94I canna help laughing at myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shan\xe2\x80\x99t loose him till he promises to let the door alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Ben, lad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, in a persuasive tone, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t let\xe2\x80\x99s have a\r\nquarrel about it. You know Adam will have his way. You may\xe2\x80\x99s well try\r\nto turn a waggon in a narrow lane. Say you\xe2\x80\x99ll leave the door alone, and\r\nmake an end on\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI binna frighted at Adam,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I donna mind sayin\xe2\x80\x99 as I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nlet \xe2\x80\x99t alone at your askin\xe2\x80\x99, Seth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, that\xe2\x80\x99s wise of you, Ben,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, laughing and relaxing his\r\ngrasp.\r\n\r\nThey all returned to their work now; but Wiry Ben, having had the worst\r\nin the bodily contest, was bent on retrieving that humiliation by a\r\nsuccess in sarcasm.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich was ye thinkin\xe2\x80\x99 on, Seth,\xe2\x80\x9d he began\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cthe pretty parson\xe2\x80\x99s face or\r\nher sarmunt, when ye forgot the panels?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and hear her, Ben,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, good-humouredly; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s going to\r\npreach on the Green to-night; happen ye\xe2\x80\x99d get something to think on\r\nyourself then, instead o\xe2\x80\x99 those wicked songs you\xe2\x80\x99re so fond on. Ye\r\nmight get religion, and that \xe2\x80\x99ud be the best day\xe2\x80\x99s earnings y\xe2\x80\x99 ever\r\nmade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll i\xe2\x80\x99 good time for that, Seth; I\xe2\x80\x99ll think about that when I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\na-goin\xe2\x80\x99 to settle i\xe2\x80\x99 life; bachelors doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want such heavy earnin\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nHappen I shall do the coortin\xe2\x80\x99 an\xe2\x80\x99 the religion both together, as _ye_\r\ndo, Seth; but ye wouldna ha\xe2\x80\x99 me get converted an\xe2\x80\x99 chop in atween ye an\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe pretty preacher, an\xe2\x80\x99 carry her aff?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo fear o\xe2\x80\x99 that, Ben; she\xe2\x80\x99s neither for you nor for me to win, I\r\ndoubt. Only you come and hear her, and you won\xe2\x80\x99t speak lightly on her\r\nagain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I\xe2\x80\x99m half a mind t\xe2\x80\x99 ha\xe2\x80\x99 a look at her to-night, if there isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ngood company at th\xe2\x80\x99 Holly Bush. What\xe2\x80\x99ll she take for her text? Happen\r\nye can tell me, Seth, if so be as I shouldna come up i\xe2\x80\x99 time for\xe2\x80\x99t.\r\nWill\xe2\x80\x99t be\xe2\x80\x94what come ye out for to see? A prophetess? Yea, I say unto\r\nyou, and more than a prophetess\xe2\x80\x94a uncommon pretty young woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Ben,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, rather sternly, \xe2\x80\x9cyou let the words o\xe2\x80\x99 the Bible\r\nalone; you\xe2\x80\x99re going too far now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Are _ye_ a-turnin\xe2\x80\x99 roun\xe2\x80\x99, Adam? I thought ye war dead again th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nwomen preachin\xe2\x80\x99, a while agoo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, I\xe2\x80\x99m not turnin\xe2\x80\x99 noway. I said nought about the women preachin\xe2\x80\x99. I\r\nsaid, You let the Bible alone: you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a jest-book, han\xe2\x80\x99t you, as\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99re rare and proud on? Keep your dirty fingers to that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, y\xe2\x80\x99 are gettin\xe2\x80\x99 as big a saint as Seth. Y\xe2\x80\x99 are goin\xe2\x80\x99 to th\xe2\x80\x99\r\npreachin\xe2\x80\x99 to-night, I should think. Ye\xe2\x80\x99ll do finely t\xe2\x80\x99 lead the\r\nsingin\xe2\x80\x99. But I don\xe2\x80\x99 know what Parson Irwine \xe2\x80\x99ull say at his gran\xe2\x80\x99\r\nfavright Adam Bede a-turnin\xe2\x80\x99 Methody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever do you bother yourself about me, Ben. I\xe2\x80\x99m not a-going to turn\r\nMethodist any more nor you are\xe2\x80\x94though it\xe2\x80\x99s like enough you\xe2\x80\x99ll turn to\r\nsomething worse. Mester Irwine\xe2\x80\x99s got more sense nor to meddle wi\xe2\x80\x99\r\npeople\xe2\x80\x99s doing as they like in religion. That\xe2\x80\x99s between themselves and\r\nGod, as he\xe2\x80\x99s said to me many a time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, aye; but he\xe2\x80\x99s none so fond o\xe2\x80\x99 your dissenters, for all that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe; I\xe2\x80\x99m none so fond o\xe2\x80\x99 Josh Tod\xe2\x80\x99s thick ale, but I don\xe2\x80\x99t hinder\r\nyou from making a fool o\xe2\x80\x99 yourself wi\xe2\x80\x99t.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThere was a laugh at this thrust of Adam\xe2\x80\x99s, but Seth said, very\r\nseriously. \xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay, Addy, thee mustna say as anybody\xe2\x80\x99s religion\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlike thick ale. Thee dostna believe but what the dissenters and the\r\nMethodists have got the root o\xe2\x80\x99 the matter as well as the church\r\nfolks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, Seth, lad; I\xe2\x80\x99m not for laughing at no man\xe2\x80\x99s religion. Let \xe2\x80\x99em\r\nfollow their consciences, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Only I think it \xe2\x80\x99ud be better if\r\ntheir consciences \xe2\x80\x99ud let \xe2\x80\x99em stay quiet i\xe2\x80\x99 the church\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s a deal\r\nto be learnt there. And there\xe2\x80\x99s such a thing as being oversperitial; we\r\nmust have something beside Gospel i\xe2\x80\x99 this world. Look at the canals,\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 aqueduc\xe2\x80\x99s, an\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 coal-pit engines, and Arkwright\xe2\x80\x99s mills\r\nthere at Cromford; a man must learn summat beside Gospel to make them\r\nthings, I reckon. But t\xe2\x80\x99 hear some o\xe2\x80\x99 them preachers, you\xe2\x80\x99d think as a\r\nman must be doing nothing all\xe2\x80\x99s life but shutting\xe2\x80\x99s eyes and looking\r\nwhat\xe2\x80\x99s agoing on inside him. I know a man must have the love o\xe2\x80\x99 God in\r\nhis soul, and the Bible\xe2\x80\x99s God\xe2\x80\x99s word. But what does the Bible say? Why,\r\nit says as God put his sperrit into the workman as built the\r\ntabernacle, to make him do all the carved work and things as wanted a\r\nnice hand. And this is my way o\xe2\x80\x99 looking at it: there\xe2\x80\x99s the sperrit o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nGod in all things and all times\xe2\x80\x94weekday as well as Sunday\xe2\x80\x94and i\xe2\x80\x99 the\r\ngreat works and inventions, and i\xe2\x80\x99 the figuring and the mechanics. And\r\nGod helps us with our headpieces and our hands as well as with our\r\nsouls; and if a man does bits o\xe2\x80\x99 jobs out o\xe2\x80\x99 working hours\xe2\x80\x94builds a\r\noven for \xe2\x80\x99s wife to save her from going to the bakehouse, or scrats at\r\nhis bit o\xe2\x80\x99 garden and makes two potatoes grow istead o\xe2\x80\x99 one, he\xe2\x80\x99s doin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nmore good, and he\xe2\x80\x99s just as near to God, as if he was running after\r\nsome preacher and a-praying and a-groaning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell done, Adam!\xe2\x80\x9d said Sandy Jim, who had paused from his planing to\r\nshift his planks while Adam was speaking; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\xe2\x80\x99s the best sarmunt I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nheared this long while. By th\xe2\x80\x99 same token, my wife\xe2\x80\x99s been a-plaguin\xe2\x80\x99 on\r\nme to build her a oven this twelvemont.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s reason in what thee say\xe2\x80\x99st, Adam,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Seth, gravely.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut thee know\xe2\x80\x99st thyself as it\xe2\x80\x99s hearing the preachers thee find\xe2\x80\x99st so\r\nmuch fault with has turned many an idle fellow into an industrious un.\r\nIt\xe2\x80\x99s the preacher as empties th\xe2\x80\x99 alehouse; and if a man gets religion,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99ll do his work none the worse for that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn\xe2\x80\x99y he\xe2\x80\x99ll lave the panels out o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 doors sometimes, eh, Seth?\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nWiry Ben.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, Ben, you\xe2\x80\x99ve got a joke again\xe2\x80\x99 me as \xe2\x80\x99ll last you your life. But it\r\nisna religion as was i\xe2\x80\x99 fault there; it was Seth Bede, as was allays a\r\nwool-gathering chap, and religion hasna cured him, the more\xe2\x80\x99s the\r\npity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNe\xe2\x80\x99er heed me, Seth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wiry Ben, \xe2\x80\x9cy\xe2\x80\x99 are a down-right good-hearted\r\nchap, panels or no panels; an\xe2\x80\x99 ye donna set up your bristles at every\r\nbit o\xe2\x80\x99 fun, like some o\xe2\x80\x99 your kin, as is mayhap cliverer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSeth, lad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, taking no notice of the sarcasm against\r\nhimself, \xe2\x80\x9cthee mustna take me unkind. I wasna driving at thee in what I\r\nsaid just now. Some \xe2\x80\x99s got one way o\xe2\x80\x99 looking at things and some \xe2\x80\x99s got\r\nanother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay, Addy, thee mean\xe2\x80\x99st me no unkindness,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, \xe2\x80\x9cI know\r\nthat well enough. Thee\xe2\x80\x99t like thy dog Gyp\xe2\x80\x94thee bark\xe2\x80\x99st at me sometimes,\r\nbut thee allays lick\xe2\x80\x99st my hand after.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll hands worked on in silence for some minutes, until the church clock\r\nbegan to strike six. Before the first stroke had died away, Sandy Jim\r\nhad loosed his plane and was reaching his jacket; Wiry Ben had left a\r\nscrew half driven in, and thrown his screwdriver into his tool-basket;\r\nMum Taft, who, true to his name, had kept silence throughout the\r\nprevious conversation, had flung down his hammer as he was in the act\r\nof lifting it; and Seth, too, had straightened his back, and was\r\nputting out his hand towards his paper cap. Adam alone had gone on with\r\nhis work as if nothing had happened. But observing the cessation of the\r\ntools, he looked up, and said, in a tone of indignation, \xe2\x80\x9cLook there,\r\nnow! I can\xe2\x80\x99t abide to see men throw away their tools i\xe2\x80\x99 that way, the\r\nminute the clock begins to strike, as if they took no pleasure i\xe2\x80\x99 their\r\nwork and was afraid o\xe2\x80\x99 doing a stroke too much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeth looked a little conscious, and began to be slower in his\r\npreparations for going, but Mum Taft broke silence, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cAye,\r\naye, Adam lad, ye talk like a young un. When y\xe2\x80\x99 are six-an\xe2\x80\x99-forty like\r\nme, istid o\xe2\x80\x99 six-an\xe2\x80\x99-twenty, ye wonna be so flush o\xe2\x80\x99 workin\xe2\x80\x99 for\r\nnought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, still wrathful; \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s age got to do with it, I\r\nwonder? Ye arena getting stiff yet, I reckon. I hate to see a man\xe2\x80\x99s\r\narms drop down as if he was shot, before the clock\xe2\x80\x99s fairly struck,\r\njust as if he\xe2\x80\x99d never a bit o\xe2\x80\x99 pride and delight in \xe2\x80\x99s work. The very\r\ngrindstone \xe2\x80\x99ull go on turning a bit after you loose it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBodderation, Adam!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Wiry Ben; \xe2\x80\x9clave a chap aloon, will \xe2\x80\x99ee?\r\nYe war afinding faut wi\xe2\x80\x99 preachers a while agoo\xe2\x80\x94y\xe2\x80\x99 are fond enough o\xe2\x80\x99\r\npreachin\xe2\x80\x99 yoursen. Ye may like work better nor play, but I like play\r\nbetter nor work; that\xe2\x80\x99ll \xe2\x80\x99commodate ye\xe2\x80\x94it laves ye th\xe2\x80\x99 more to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith this exit speech, which he considered effective, Wiry Ben\r\nshouldered his basket and left the workshop, quickly followed by Mum\r\nTaft and Sandy Jim. Seth lingered, and looked wistfully at Adam, as if\r\nhe expected him to say something.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShalt go home before thee go\xe2\x80\x99st to the preaching?\xe2\x80\x9d Adam asked, looking\r\nup.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay; I\xe2\x80\x99ve got my hat and things at Will Maskery\xe2\x80\x99s. I shan\xe2\x80\x99t be home\r\nbefore going for ten. I\xe2\x80\x99ll happen see Dinah Morris safe home, if she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwilling. There\xe2\x80\x99s nobody comes with her from Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s, thee know\xe2\x80\x99st.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell mother not to look for thee,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThee artna going to Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s thyself to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth rather\r\ntimidly, as he turned to leave the workshop.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, I\xe2\x80\x99m going to th\xe2\x80\x99 school.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHitherto Gyp had kept his comfortable bed, only lifting up his head and\r\nwatching Adam more closely as he noticed the other workmen departing.\r\nBut no sooner did Adam put his ruler in his pocket, and begin to twist\r\nhis apron round his waist, than Gyp ran forward and looked up in his\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s face with patient expectation. If Gyp had had a tail he would\r\ndoubtless have wagged it, but being destitute of that vehicle for his\r\nemotions, he was like many other worthy personages, destined to appear\r\nmore phlegmatic than nature had made him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! Art ready for the basket, eh, Gyp?\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, with the same\r\ngentle modulation of voice as when he spoke to Seth.\r\n\r\nGyp jumped and gave a short bark, as much as to say, \xe2\x80\x9cOf course.\xe2\x80\x9d Poor\r\nfellow, he had not a great range of expression.\r\n\r\nThe basket was the one which on workdays held Adam\xe2\x80\x99s and Seth\xe2\x80\x99s dinner;\r\nand no official, walking in procession, could look more resolutely\r\nunconscious of all acquaintances than Gyp with his basket, trotting at\r\nhis master\xe2\x80\x99s heels.\r\n\r\nOn leaving the workshop Adam locked the door, took the key out, and\r\ncarried it to the house on the other side of the woodyard. It was a low\r\nhouse, with smooth grey thatch and buff walls, looking pleasant and\r\nmellow in the evening light. The leaded windows were bright and\r\nspeckless, and the door-stone was as clean as a white boulder at ebb\r\ntide. On the door-stone stood a clean old woman, in a dark-striped\r\nlinen gown, a red kerchief, and a linen cap, talking to some speckled\r\nfowls which appeared to have been drawn towards her by an illusory\r\nexpectation of cold potatoes or barley. The old woman\xe2\x80\x99s sight seemed to\r\nbe dim, for she did not recognize Adam till he said, \xe2\x80\x9cHere\xe2\x80\x99s the key,\r\nDolly; lay it down for me in the house, will you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, sure; but wunna ye come in, Adam? Miss Mary\xe2\x80\x99s i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 house, and\r\nMester Burge \xe2\x80\x99ull be back anon; he\xe2\x80\x99d be glad t\xe2\x80\x99 ha\xe2\x80\x99 ye to supper wi\xe2\x80\x99m,\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ll be\xe2\x80\x99s warrand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Dolly, thank you; I\xe2\x80\x99m off home. Good evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAdam hastened with long strides, Gyp close to his heels, out of the\r\nworkyard, and along the highroad leading away from the village and down\r\nto the valley. As he reached the foot of the slope, an elderly\r\nhorseman, with his portmanteau strapped behind him, stopped his horse\r\nwhen Adam had passed him, and turned round to have another long look at\r\nthe stalwart workman in paper cap, leather breeches, and dark-blue\r\nworsted stockings.\r\n\r\nAdam, unconscious of the admiration he was exciting, presently struck\r\nacross the fields, and now broke out into the tune which had all day\r\nlong been running in his head:\r\n\r\nLet all thy converse be sincere,\r\nThy conscience as the noonday clear;\r\nFor God\xe2\x80\x99s all-seeing eye surveys\r\nThy secret thoughts, thy works and ways.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter II\r\nThe Preaching\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout a quarter to seven there was an unusual appearance of excitement\r\nin the village of Hayslope, and through the whole length of its little\r\nstreet, from the Donnithorne Arms to the churchyard gate, the\r\ninhabitants had evidently been drawn out of their houses by something\r\nmore than the pleasure of lounging in the evening sunshine. The\r\nDonnithorne Arms stood at the entrance of the village, and a small\r\nfarmyard and stackyard which flanked it, indicating that there was a\r\npretty take of land attached to the inn, gave the traveller a promise\r\nof good feed for himself and his horse, which might well console him\r\nfor the ignorance in which the weather-beaten sign left him as to the\r\nheraldic bearings of that ancient family, the Donnithornes. Mr. Casson,\r\nthe landlord, had been for some time standing at the door with his\r\nhands in his pockets, balancing himself on his heels and toes and\r\nlooking towards a piece of unenclosed ground, with a maple in the\r\nmiddle of it, which he knew to be the destination of certain\r\ngrave-looking men and women whom he had observed passing at intervals.\r\n\r\nMr. Casson\xe2\x80\x99s person was by no means of that common type which can be\r\nallowed to pass without description. On a front view it appeared to\r\nconsist principally of two spheres, bearing about the same relation to\r\neach other as the earth and the moon: that is to say, the lower sphere\r\nmight be said, at a rough guess, to be thirteen times larger than the\r\nupper which naturally performed the function of a mere satellite and\r\ntributary. But here the resemblance ceased, for Mr. Casson\xe2\x80\x99s head was\r\nnot at all a melancholy-looking satellite nor was it a \xe2\x80\x9cspotty globe,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nas Milton has irreverently called the moon; on the contrary, no head\r\nand face could look more sleek and healthy, and its expression\xe2\x80\x94which\r\nwas chiefly confined to a pair of round and ruddy cheeks, the slight\r\nknot and interruptions forming the nose and eyes being scarcely worth\r\nmention\xe2\x80\x94was one of jolly contentment, only tempered by that sense of\r\npersonal dignity which usually made itself felt in his attitude and\r\nbearing. This sense of dignity could hardly be considered excessive in\r\na man who had been butler to \xe2\x80\x9cthe family\xe2\x80\x9d for fifteen years, and who,\r\nin his present high position, was necessarily very much in contact with\r\nhis inferiors. How to reconcile his dignity with the satisfaction of\r\nhis curiosity by walking towards the Green was the problem that Mr.\r\nCasson had been revolving in his mind for the last five minutes; but\r\nwhen he had partly solved it by taking his hands out of his pockets,\r\nand thrusting them into the armholes of his waistcoat, by throwing his\r\nhead on one side, and providing himself with an air of contemptuous\r\nindifference to whatever might fall under his notice, his thoughts were\r\ndiverted by the approach of the horseman whom we lately saw pausing to\r\nhave another look at our friend Adam, and who now pulled up at the door\r\nof the Donnithorne Arms.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake off the bridle and give him a drink, ostler,\xe2\x80\x9d said the traveller\r\nto the lad in a smock-frock, who had come out of the yard at the sound\r\nof the horse\xe2\x80\x99s hoofs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, what\xe2\x80\x99s up in your pretty village, landlord?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\r\ngetting down. \xe2\x80\x9cThere seems to be quite a stir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a Methodis\xe2\x80\x99 preaching, sir; it\xe2\x80\x99s been gev hout as a young woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\na-going to preach on the Green,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mr. Casson, in a treble and\r\nwheezy voice, with a slightly mincing accent. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you please to step\r\nin, sir, an\xe2\x80\x99 tek somethink?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I must be getting on to Rosseter. I only want a drink for my\r\nhorse. And what does your parson say, I wonder, to a young woman\r\npreaching just under his nose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cParson Irwine, sir, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t live here; he lives at Brox\xe2\x80\x99on, over the\r\nhill there. The parsonage here\xe2\x80\x99s a tumble-down place, sir, not fit for\r\ngentry to live in. He comes here to preach of a Sunday afternoon, sir,\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 puts up his hoss here. It\xe2\x80\x99s a grey cob, sir, an\xe2\x80\x99 he sets great\r\nstore by\xe2\x80\x99t. He\xe2\x80\x99s allays put up his hoss here, sir, iver since before I\r\nhed the Donnithorne Arms. I\xe2\x80\x99m not this countryman, you may tell by my\r\ntongue, sir. They\xe2\x80\x99re cur\xe2\x80\x99ous talkers i\xe2\x80\x99 this country, sir; the gentry\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhard work to hunderstand \xe2\x80\x99em. I was brought hup among the gentry, sir,\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 got the turn o\xe2\x80\x99 their tongue when I was a bye. Why, what do you\r\nthink the folks here says for \xe2\x80\x98hevn\xe2\x80\x99t you?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94the gentry, you know, says,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98hevn\xe2\x80\x99t you\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94well, the people about here says \xe2\x80\x98hanna yey.\xe2\x80\x99 It\xe2\x80\x99s what\r\nthey call the dileck as is spoke hereabout, sir. That\xe2\x80\x99s what I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nheared Squire Donnithorne say many a time; it\xe2\x80\x99s the dileck, says he.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, aye,\xe2\x80\x9d said the stranger, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cI know it very well. But\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ve not got many Methodists about here, surely\xe2\x80\x94in this agricultural\r\nspot? I should have thought there would hardly be such a thing as a\r\nMethodist to be found about here. You\xe2\x80\x99re all farmers, aren\xe2\x80\x99t you? The\r\nMethodists can seldom lay much hold on _them_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, sir, there\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty lot o\xe2\x80\x99 workmen round about, sir. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nMester Burge as owns the timber-yard over there, he underteks a good\r\nbit o\xe2\x80\x99 building an\xe2\x80\x99 repairs. An\xe2\x80\x99 there\xe2\x80\x99s the stone-pits not far off.\r\nThere\xe2\x80\x99s plenty of emply i\xe2\x80\x99 this countryside, sir. An\xe2\x80\x99 there\xe2\x80\x99s a fine\r\nbatch o\xe2\x80\x99 Methodisses at Treddles\xe2\x80\x99on\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s the market town about three\r\nmile off\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99ll maybe ha\xe2\x80\x99 come through it, sir. There\xe2\x80\x99s pretty nigh a\r\nscore of \xe2\x80\x99em on the Green now, as come from there. That\xe2\x80\x99s where our\r\npeople gets it from, though there\xe2\x80\x99s only two men of \xe2\x80\x99em in all\r\nHayslope: that\xe2\x80\x99s Will Maskery, the wheelwright, and Seth Bede, a young\r\nman as works at the carpenterin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe preacher comes from Treddleston, then, does she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, sir, she comes out o\xe2\x80\x99 Stonyshire, pretty nigh thirty mile off.\r\nBut she\xe2\x80\x99s a-visitin\xe2\x80\x99 hereabout at Mester Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s at the Hall Farm\xe2\x80\x94it\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthem barns an\xe2\x80\x99 big walnut-trees, right away to the left, sir. She\xe2\x80\x99s own\r\nniece to Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s wife, an\xe2\x80\x99 they\xe2\x80\x99ll be fine an\xe2\x80\x99 vexed at her for making\r\na fool of herself i\xe2\x80\x99 that way. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve heared as there\xe2\x80\x99s no holding\r\nthese Methodisses when the maggit\xe2\x80\x99s once got i\xe2\x80\x99 their head: many of \xe2\x80\x99em\r\ngoes stark starin\xe2\x80\x99 mad wi\xe2\x80\x99 their religion. Though this young woman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nquiet enough to look at, by what I can make out; I\xe2\x80\x99ve not seen her\r\nmyself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I wish I had time to wait and see her, but I must get on. I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen out of my way for the last twenty minutes to have a look at that\r\nplace in the valley. It\xe2\x80\x99s Squire Donnithorne\xe2\x80\x99s, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, that\xe2\x80\x99s Donnithorne Chase, that is. Fine hoaks there, isn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nthere, sir? I should know what it is, sir, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve lived butler there\r\na-going i\xe2\x80\x99 fifteen year. It\xe2\x80\x99s Captain Donnithorne as is th\xe2\x80\x99 heir,\r\nsir\xe2\x80\x94Squire Donnithorne\xe2\x80\x99s grandson. He\xe2\x80\x99ll be comin\xe2\x80\x99 of hage this\r\n\xe2\x80\x99ay-\xe2\x80\x99arvest, sir, an\xe2\x80\x99 we shall hev fine doin\xe2\x80\x99s. He owns all the land\r\nabout here, sir, Squire Donnithorne does.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it\xe2\x80\x99s a pretty spot, whoever may own it,\xe2\x80\x9d said the traveller,\r\nmounting his horse; \xe2\x80\x9cand one meets some fine strapping fellows about\r\ntoo. I met as fine a young fellow as ever I saw in my life, about half\r\nan hour ago, before I came up the hill\xe2\x80\x94a carpenter, a tall,\r\nbroad-shouldered fellow with black hair and black eyes, marching along\r\nlike a soldier. We want such fellows as he to lick the French.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, sir, that\xe2\x80\x99s Adam Bede, that is, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be bound\xe2\x80\x94Thias Bede\xe2\x80\x99s son\r\neverybody knows him hereabout. He\xe2\x80\x99s an uncommon clever stiddy fellow,\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 wonderful strong. Lord bless you, sir\xe2\x80\x94if you\xe2\x80\x99ll hexcuse me for\r\nsaying so\xe2\x80\x94he can walk forty mile a-day, an\xe2\x80\x99 lift a matter o\xe2\x80\x99 sixty\r\nston\xe2\x80\x99. He\xe2\x80\x99s an uncommon favourite wi\xe2\x80\x99 the gentry, sir: Captain\r\nDonnithorne and Parson Irwine meks a fine fuss wi\xe2\x80\x99 him. But he\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nlittle lifted up an\xe2\x80\x99 peppery-like.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, good evening to you, landlord; I must get on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour servant, sir; good evenin\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe traveller put his horse into a quick walk up the village, but when\r\nhe approached the Green, the beauty of the view that lay on his right\r\nhand, the singular contrast presented by the groups of villagers with\r\nthe knot of Methodists near the maple, and perhaps yet more, curiosity\r\nto see the young female preacher, proved too much for his anxiety to\r\nget to the end of his journey, and he paused.\r\n\r\nThe Green lay at the extremity of the village, and from it the road\r\nbranched off in two directions, one leading farther up the hill by the\r\nchurch, and the other winding gently down towards the valley. On the\r\nside of the Green that led towards the church, the broken line of\r\nthatched cottages was continued nearly to the churchyard gate; but on\r\nthe opposite northwestern side, there was nothing to obstruct the view\r\nof gently swelling meadow, and wooded valley, and dark masses of\r\ndistant hill. That rich undulating district of Loamshire to which\r\nHayslope belonged lies close to a grim outskirt of Stonyshire,\r\noverlooked by its barren hills as a pretty blooming sister may\r\nsometimes be seen linked in the arm of a rugged, tall, swarthy brother;\r\nand in two or three hours\xe2\x80\x99 ride the traveller might exchange a bleak\r\ntreeless region, intersected by lines of cold grey stone, for one where\r\nhis road wound under the shelter of woods, or up swelling hills,\r\nmuffled with hedgerows and long meadow-grass and thick corn; and where\r\nat every turn he came upon some fine old country-seat nestled in the\r\nvalley or crowning the slope, some homestead with its long length of\r\nbarn and its cluster of golden ricks, some grey steeple looking out\r\nfrom a pretty confusion of trees and thatch and dark-red tiles. It was\r\njust such a picture as this last that Hayslope Church had made to the\r\ntraveller as he began to mount the gentle slope leading to its pleasant\r\nuplands, and now from his station near the Green he had before him in\r\none view nearly all the other typical features of this pleasant land.\r\nHigh up against the horizon were the huge conical masses of hill, like\r\ngiant mounds intended to fortify this region of corn and grass against\r\nthe keen and hungry winds of the north; not distant enough to be\r\nclothed in purple mystery, but with sombre greenish sides visibly\r\nspecked with sheep, whose motion was only revealed by memory, not\r\ndetected by sight; wooed from day to day by the changing hours, but\r\nresponding with no change in themselves\xe2\x80\x94left for ever grim and sullen\r\nafter the flush of morning, the winged gleams of the April noonday, the\r\nparting crimson glory of the ripening summer sun. And directly below\r\nthem the eye rested on a more advanced line of hanging woods, divided\r\nby bright patches of pasture or furrowed crops, and not yet deepened\r\ninto the uniform leafy curtains of high summer, but still showing the\r\nwarm tints of the young oak and the tender green of the ash and lime.\r\nThen came the valley, where the woods grew thicker, as if they had\r\nrolled down and hurried together from the patches left smooth on the\r\nslope, that they might take the better care of the tall mansion which\r\nlifted its parapets and sent its faint blue summer smoke among them.\r\nDoubtless there was a large sweep of park and a broad glassy pool in\r\nfront of that mansion, but the swelling slope of meadow would not let\r\nour traveller see them from the village green. He saw instead a\r\nforeground which was just as lovely\xe2\x80\x94the level sunlight lying like\r\ntransparent gold among the gently curving stems of the feathered grass\r\nand the tall red sorrel, and the white ambels of the hemlocks lining\r\nthe bushy hedgerows. It was that moment in summer when the sound of the\r\nscythe being whetted makes us cast more lingering looks at the\r\nflower-sprinkled tresses of the meadows.\r\n\r\nHe might have seen other beauties in the landscape if he had turned a\r\nlittle in his saddle and looked eastward, beyond Jonathan Burge\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npasture and woodyard towards the green corn-fields and walnut-trees of\r\nthe Hall Farm; but apparently there was more interest for him in the\r\nliving groups close at hand. Every generation in the village was there,\r\nfrom old \xe2\x80\x9cFeyther Taft\xe2\x80\x9d in his brown worsted night-cap, who was bent\r\nnearly double, but seemed tough enough to keep on his legs a long\r\nwhile, leaning on his short stick, down to the babies with their little\r\nround heads lolling forward in quilted linen caps. Now and then there\r\nwas a new arrival; perhaps a slouching labourer, who, having eaten his\r\nsupper, came out to look at the unusual scene with a slow bovine gaze,\r\nwilling to hear what any one had to say in explanation of it, but by no\r\nmeans excited enough to ask a question. But all took care not to join\r\nthe Methodists on the Green, and identify themselves in that way with\r\nthe expectant audience, for there was not one of them that would not\r\nhave disclaimed the imputation of having come out to hear the \xe2\x80\x9cpreacher\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94they had only come out to see \xe2\x80\x9cwhat war a-goin\xe2\x80\x99 on, like.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nmen were chiefly gathered in the neighbourhood of the blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshop. But do not imagine them gathered in a knot. Villagers never\r\nswarm: a whisper is unknown among them, and they seem almost as\r\nincapable of an undertone as a cow or a stag. Your true rustic turns\r\nhis back on his interlocutor, throwing a question over his shoulder as\r\nif he meant to run away from the answer, and walking a step or two\r\nfarther off when the interest of the dialogue culminates. So the group\r\nin the vicinity of the blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s door was by no means a close one,\r\nand formed no screen in front of Chad Cranage, the blacksmith himself,\r\nwho stood with his black brawny arms folded, leaning against the\r\ndoor-post, and occasionally sending forth a bellowing laugh at his own\r\njokes, giving them a marked preference over the sarcasms of Wiry Ben,\r\nwho had renounced the pleasures of the Holly Bush for the sake of\r\nseeing life under a new form. But both styles of wit were treated with\r\nequal contempt by Mr. Joshua Rann. Mr. Rann\xe2\x80\x99s leathern apron and\r\nsubdued griminess can leave no one in any doubt that he is the village\r\nshoemaker; the thrusting out of his chin and stomach and the twirling\r\nof his thumbs are more subtle indications, intended to prepare unwary\r\nstrangers for the discovery that they are in the presence of the parish\r\nclerk. \xe2\x80\x9cOld Joshway,\xe2\x80\x9d as he is irreverently called by his neighbours,\r\nis in a state of simmering indignation; but he has not yet opened his\r\nlips except to say, in a resounding bass undertone, like the tuning of\r\na violoncello, \xe2\x80\x9cSehon, King of the Amorites; for His mercy endureth for\r\never; and Og the King of Basan: for His mercy endureth for ever\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nquotation which may seem to have slight bearing on the present\r\noccasion, but, as with every other anomaly, adequate knowledge will\r\nshow it to be a natural sequence. Mr. Rann was inwardly maintaining the\r\ndignity of the Church in the face of this scandalous irruption of\r\nMethodism, and as that dignity was bound up with his own sonorous\r\nutterance of the responses, his argument naturally suggested a\r\nquotation from the psalm he had read the last Sunday afternoon.\r\n\r\nThe stronger curiosity of the women had drawn them quite to the edge of\r\nthe Green, where they could examine more closely the Quakerlike costume\r\nand odd deportment of the female Methodists. Underneath the maple there\r\nwas a small cart, which had been brought from the wheelwright\xe2\x80\x99s to\r\nserve as a pulpit, and round this a couple of benches and a few chairs\r\nhad been placed. Some of the Methodists were resting on these, with\r\ntheir eyes closed, as if wrapt in prayer or meditation. Others chose to\r\ncontinue standing, and had turned their faces towards the villagers\r\nwith a look of melancholy compassion, which was highly amusing to Bessy\r\nCranage, the blacksmith\xe2\x80\x99s buxom daughter, known to her neighbours as\r\nChad\xe2\x80\x99s Bess, who wondered \xe2\x80\x9cwhy the folks war amakin\xe2\x80\x99 faces a that\xe2\x80\x99ns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nChad\xe2\x80\x99s Bess was the object of peculiar compassion, because her hair,\r\nbeing turned back under a cap which was set at the top of her head,\r\nexposed to view an ornament of which she was much prouder than of her\r\nred cheeks\xe2\x80\x94namely, a pair of large round ear-rings with false garnets\r\nin them, ornaments condemned not only by the Methodists, but by her own\r\ncousin and namesake Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s Bess, who, with much cousinly feeling,\r\noften wished \xe2\x80\x9cthem ear-rings\xe2\x80\x9d might come to good.\r\n\r\nTimothy\xe2\x80\x99s Bess, though retaining her maiden appellation among her\r\nfamiliars, had long been the wife of Sandy Jim, and possessed a\r\nhandsome set of matronly jewels, of which it is enough to mention the\r\nheavy baby she was rocking in her arms, and the sturdy fellow of five\r\nin knee-breeches, and red legs, who had a rusty milk-can round his neck\r\nby way of drum, and was very carefully avoided by Chad\xe2\x80\x99s small terrier.\r\nThis young olive-branch, notorious under the name of Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s Bess\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nBen, being of an inquiring disposition, unchecked by any false modesty,\r\nhad advanced beyond the group of women and children, and was walking\r\nround the Methodists, looking up in their faces with his mouth wide\r\nopen, and beating his stick against the milk-can by way of musical\r\naccompaniment. But one of the elderly women bending down to take him by\r\nthe shoulder, with an air of grave remonstrance, Timothy\xe2\x80\x99s Bess\xe2\x80\x99s Ben\r\nfirst kicked out vigorously, then took to his heels and sought refuge\r\nbehind his father\xe2\x80\x99s legs.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe gallows young dog,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sandy Jim, with some paternal pride, \xe2\x80\x9cif\r\nye donna keep that stick quiet, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tek it from ye. What dy\xe2\x80\x99e mane by\r\nkickin\xe2\x80\x99 foulks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere! Gie him here to me, Jim,\xe2\x80\x9d said Chad Cranage; \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tie hirs up\r\nan\xe2\x80\x99 shoe him as I do th\xe2\x80\x99 hosses. Well, Mester Casson,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, as\r\nthat personage sauntered up towards the group of men, \xe2\x80\x9chow are ye t\xe2\x80\x99\r\nnaight? Are ye coom t\xe2\x80\x99 help groon? They say folks allays groon when\r\nthey\xe2\x80\x99re hearkenin\xe2\x80\x99 to th\xe2\x80\x99 Methodys, as if they war bad i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 inside. I\r\nmane to groon as loud as your cow did th\xe2\x80\x99 other naight, an\xe2\x80\x99 then the\r\npraicher \xe2\x80\x99ull think I\xe2\x80\x99m i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 raight way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d advise you not to be up to no nonsense, Chad,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Casson,\r\nwith some dignity; \xe2\x80\x9cPoyser wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like to hear as his wife\xe2\x80\x99s niece\r\nwas treated any ways disrespectful, for all he mayn\xe2\x80\x99t be fond of her\r\ntaking on herself to preach.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, an\xe2\x80\x99 she\xe2\x80\x99s a pleasant-looked un too,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wiry Ben. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll stick\r\nup for the pretty women preachin\xe2\x80\x99; I know they\xe2\x80\x99d persuade me over a\r\ndeal sooner nor th\xe2\x80\x99 ugly men. I shouldna wonder if I turn Methody afore\r\nthe night\xe2\x80\x99s out, an\xe2\x80\x99 begin to coort the preacher, like Seth Bede.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Seth\xe2\x80\x99s looking rether too high, I should think,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Casson.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis woman\xe2\x80\x99s kin wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t like her to demean herself to a common\r\ncarpenter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTchu!\xe2\x80\x9d said Ben, with a long treble intonation, \xe2\x80\x9cwhat\xe2\x80\x99s folks\xe2\x80\x99s kin\r\ngot to do wi\xe2\x80\x99t? Not a chip. Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s wife may turn her nose up an\xe2\x80\x99\r\nforget bygones, but this Dinah Morris, they tell me, \xe2\x80\x99s as poor as iver\r\nshe was\xe2\x80\x94works at a mill, an\xe2\x80\x99s much ado to keep hersen. A strappin\xe2\x80\x99\r\nyoung carpenter as is a ready-made Methody, like Seth, wouldna be a bad\r\nmatch for her. Why, Poysers make as big a fuss wi\xe2\x80\x99 Adam Bede as if he\r\nwar a nevvy o\xe2\x80\x99 their own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIdle talk! idle talk!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Joshua Rann. \xe2\x80\x9cAdam an\xe2\x80\x99 Seth\xe2\x80\x99s two men;\r\nyou wunna fit them two wi\xe2\x80\x99 the same last.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaybe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wiry Ben, contemptuously, \xe2\x80\x9cbut Seth\xe2\x80\x99s the lad for me,\r\nthough he war a Methody twice o\xe2\x80\x99er. I\xe2\x80\x99m fair beat wi\xe2\x80\x99 Seth, for I\xe2\x80\x99ve\r\nbeen teasin\xe2\x80\x99 him iver sin\xe2\x80\x99 we\xe2\x80\x99ve been workin\xe2\x80\x99 together, an\xe2\x80\x99 he bears me\r\nno more malice nor a lamb. An\xe2\x80\x99 he\xe2\x80\x99s a stout-hearted feller too, for\r\nwhen we saw the old tree all afire a-comin\xe2\x80\x99 across the fields one\r\nnight, an\xe2\x80\x99 we thought as it war a boguy, Seth made no more ado, but he\r\nup to\xe2\x80\x99t as bold as a constable. Why, there he comes out o\xe2\x80\x99 Will\r\nMaskery\xe2\x80\x99s; an\xe2\x80\x99 there\xe2\x80\x99s Will hisself, lookin\xe2\x80\x99 as meek as if he couldna\r\nknock a nail o\xe2\x80\x99 the head for fear o\xe2\x80\x99 hurtin\xe2\x80\x99t. An\xe2\x80\x99 there\xe2\x80\x99s the pretty\r\npreacher woman! My eye, she\xe2\x80\x99s got her bonnet off. I mun go a bit\r\nnearer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeveral of the men followed Ben\xe2\x80\x99s lead, and the traveller pushed his\r\nhorse on to the Green, as Dinah walked rather quickly and in advance of\r\nher companions towards the cart under the maple-tree. While she was\r\nnear Seth\xe2\x80\x99s tall figure, she looked short, but when she had mounted the\r\ncart, and was away from all comparison, she seemed above the middle\r\nheight of woman, though in reality she did not exceed it\xe2\x80\x94an effect\r\nwhich was due to the slimness of her figure and the simple line of her\r\nblack stuff dress. The stranger was struck with surprise as he saw her\r\napproach and mount the cart\xe2\x80\x94surprise, not so much at the feminine\r\ndelicacy of her appearance, as at the total absence of\r\nself-consciousness in her demeanour. He had made up his mind to see her\r\nadvance with a measured step and a demure solemnity of countenance; he\r\nhad felt sure that her face would be mantled with the smile of\r\nconscious saintship, or else charged with denunciatory bitterness. He\r\nknew but two types of Methodist\xe2\x80\x94the ecstatic and the bilious. But Dinah\r\nwalked as simply as if she were going to market, and seemed as\r\nunconscious of her outward appearance as a little boy: there was no\r\nblush, no tremulousness, which said, \xe2\x80\x9cI know you think me a pretty\r\nwoman, too young to preach\xe2\x80\x9d; no casting up or down of the eyelids, no\r\ncompression of the lips, no attitude of the arms that said, \xe2\x80\x9cBut you\r\nmust think of me as a saint.\xe2\x80\x9d She held no book in her ungloved hands,\r\nbut let them hang down lightly crossed before her, as she stood and\r\nturned her grey eyes on the people. There was no keenness in the eyes;\r\nthey seemed rather to be shedding love than making observations; they\r\nhad the liquid look which tells that the mind is full of what it has to\r\ngive out, rather than impressed by external objects. She stood with her\r\nleft hand towards the descending sun, and leafy boughs screened her\r\nfrom its rays; but in this sober light the delicate colouring of her\r\nface seemed to gather a calm vividness, like flowers at evening. It was\r\na small oval face, of a uniform transparent whiteness, with an egg-like\r\nline of cheek and chin, a full but firm mouth, a delicate nostril, and\r\na low perpendicular brow, surmounted by a rising arch of parting\r\nbetween smooth locks of pale reddish hair. The hair was drawn straight\r\nback behind the ears, and covered, except for an inch or two above the\r\nbrow, by a net Quaker cap. The eyebrows, of the same colour as the\r\nhair, were perfectly horizontal and firmly pencilled; the eyelashes,\r\nthough no darker, were long and abundant\xe2\x80\x94nothing was left blurred or\r\nunfinished. It was one of those faces that make one think of white\r\nflowers with light touches of colour on their pure petals. The eyes had\r\nno peculiar beauty, beyond that of expression; they looked so simple,\r\nso candid, so gravely loving, that no accusing scowl, no light sneer\r\ncould help melting away before their glance. Joshua Rann gave a long\r\ncough, as if he were clearing his throat in order to come to a new\r\nunderstanding with himself; Chad Cranage lifted up his leather\r\nskull-cap and scratched his head; and Wiry Ben wondered how Seth had\r\nthe pluck to think of courting her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA sweet woman,\xe2\x80\x9d the stranger said to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cbut surely nature never\r\nmeant her for a preacher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPerhaps he was one of those who think that nature has theatrical\r\nproperties and, with the considerate view of facilitating art and\r\npsychology, \xe2\x80\x9cmakes up,\xe2\x80\x9d her characters, so that there may be no mistake\r\nabout them. But Dinah began to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear friends,\xe2\x80\x9d she said in a clear but not loud voice \xe2\x80\x9clet us pray for\r\na blessing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe closed her eyes, and hanging her head down a little continued in\r\nthe same moderate tone, as if speaking to some one quite near her:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSaviour of sinners! When a poor woman laden with sins, went out to the\r\nwell to draw water, she found Thee sitting at the well. She knew Thee\r\nnot; she had not sought Thee; her mind was dark; her life was unholy.\r\nBut Thou didst speak to her, Thou didst teach her, Thou didst show her\r\nthat her life lay open before Thee, and yet Thou wast ready to give her\r\nthat blessing which she had never sought. Jesus, Thou art in the midst\r\nof us, and Thou knowest all men: if there is any here like that poor\r\nwoman\xe2\x80\x94if their minds are dark, their lives unholy\xe2\x80\x94if they have come out\r\nnot seeking Thee, not desiring to be taught; deal with them according\r\nto the free mercy which Thou didst show to her. Speak to them, Lord,\r\nopen their ears to my message, bring their sins to their minds, and\r\nmake them thirst for that salvation which Thou art ready to give.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLord, Thou art with Thy people still: they see Thee in the\r\nnight-watches, and their hearts burn within them as Thou talkest with\r\nthem by the way. And Thou art near to those who have not known Thee:\r\nopen their eyes that they may see Thee\xe2\x80\x94see Thee weeping over them, and\r\nsaying \xe2\x80\x98Ye will not come unto me that ye might have life\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94see Thee\r\nhanging on the cross and saying, \xe2\x80\x98Father, forgive them, for they know\r\nnot what they do\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94see Thee as Thou wilt come again in Thy glory to\r\njudge them at the last. Amen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDinah opened her eyes again and paused, looking at the group of\r\nvillagers, who were now gathered rather more closely on her right hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear friends,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, raising her voice a little, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have all of\r\nyou been to church, and I think you must have heard the clergyman read\r\nthese words: \xe2\x80\x98The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he hath\r\nanointed me to preach the gospel to the poor.\xe2\x80\x99 Jesus Christ spoke those\r\nwords\xe2\x80\x94he said he came _to preach the Gospel to the poor:_ I don\xe2\x80\x99t know\r\nwhether you ever thought about those words much, but I will tell you\r\nwhen I remember first hearing them. It was on just such a sort of\r\nevening as this, when I was a little girl, and my aunt as brought me up\r\ntook me to hear a good man preach out of doors, just as we are here. I\r\nremember his face well: he was a very old man, and had very long white\r\nhair; his voice was very soft and beautiful, not like any voice I had\r\never heard before. I was a little girl and scarcely knew anything, and\r\nthis old man seemed to me such a different sort of a man from anybody I\r\nhad ever seen before that I thought he had perhaps come down from the\r\nsky to preach to us, and I said, \xe2\x80\x98Aunt, will he go back to the sky\r\nto-night, like the picture in the Bible?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat man of God was Mr. Wesley, who spent his life in doing what our\r\nblessed Lord did\xe2\x80\x94preaching the Gospel to the poor\xe2\x80\x94and he entered into\r\nhis rest eight years ago. I came to know more about him years after,\r\nbut I was a foolish thoughtless child then, and I remembered only one\r\nthing he told us in his sermon. He told us as \xe2\x80\x98Gospel\xe2\x80\x99 meant \xe2\x80\x98good\r\nnews.\xe2\x80\x99 The Gospel, you know, is what the Bible tells us about God.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThink of that now! Jesus Christ did really come down from heaven, as\r\nI, like a silly child, thought Mr. Wesley did; and what he came down\r\nfor was to tell good news about God to the poor. Why, you and me, dear\r\nfriends, are poor. We have been brought up in poor cottages and have\r\nbeen reared on oat-cake, and lived coarse; and we haven\xe2\x80\x99t been to\r\nschool much, nor read books, and we don\xe2\x80\x99t know much about anything but\r\nwhat happens just round us. We are just the sort of people that want to\r\nhear good news. For when anybody\xe2\x80\x99s well off, they don\xe2\x80\x99t much mind about\r\nhearing news from distant parts; but if a poor man or woman\xe2\x80\x99s in\r\ntrouble and has hard work to make out a living, they like to have a\r\nletter to tell \xe2\x80\x99em they\xe2\x80\x99ve got a friend as will help \xe2\x80\x99em. To be sure,\r\nwe can\xe2\x80\x99t help knowing something about God, even if we\xe2\x80\x99ve never heard\r\nthe Gospel, the good news that our Saviour brought us. For we know\r\neverything comes from God: don\xe2\x80\x99t you say almost every day, \xe2\x80\x98This and\r\nthat will happen, please God,\xe2\x80\x99 and \xe2\x80\x98We shall begin to cut the grass\r\nsoon, please God to send us a little more sunshine\xe2\x80\x99? We know very well\r\nwe are altogether in the hands of God. We didn\xe2\x80\x99t bring ourselves into\r\nthe world, we can\xe2\x80\x99t keep ourselves alive while we\xe2\x80\x99re sleeping; the\r\ndaylight, and the wind, and the corn, and the cows to give us\r\nmilk\xe2\x80\x94everything we have comes from God. And he gave us our souls and\r\nput love between parents and children, and husband and wife. But is\r\nthat as much as we want to know about God? We see he is great and\r\nmighty, and can do what he will: we are lost, as if we was struggling\r\nin great waters, when we try to think of him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut perhaps doubts come into your mind like this: Can God take much\r\nnotice of us poor people? Perhaps he only made the world for the great\r\nand the wise and the rich. It doesn\xe2\x80\x99t cost him much to give us our\r\nlittle handful of victual and bit of clothing; but how do we know he\r\ncares for us any more than we care for the worms and things in the\r\ngarden, so as we rear our carrots and onions? Will God take care of us\r\nwhen we die? And has he any comfort for us when we are lame and sick\r\nand helpless? Perhaps, too, he is angry with us; else why does the\r\nblight come, and the bad harvests, and the fever, and all sorts of pain\r\nand trouble? For our life is full of trouble, and if God sends us good,\r\nhe seems to send bad too. How is it? How is it?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, dear friends, we are in sad want of good news about God; and what\r\ndoes other good news signify if we haven\xe2\x80\x99t that? For everything else\r\ncomes to an end, and when we die we leave it all. But God lasts when\r\neverything else is gone. What shall we do if he is not our friend?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Dinah told how the good news had been brought, and how the mind of\r\nGod towards the poor had been made manifest in the life of Jesus,\r\ndwelling on its lowliness and its acts of mercy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo you see, dear friends,\xe2\x80\x9d she went on, \xe2\x80\x9cJesus spent his time almost\r\nall in doing good to poor people; he preached out of doors to them, and\r\nhe made friends of poor workmen, and taught them and took pains with\r\nthem. Not but what he did good to the rich too, for he was full of love\r\nto all men, only he saw as the poor were more in want of his help. So\r\nhe cured the lame and the sick and the blind, and he worked miracles to\r\nfeed the hungry because, he said, he was sorry for them; and he was\r\nvery kind to the little children and comforted those who had lost their\r\nfriends; and he spoke very tenderly to poor sinners that were sorry for\r\ntheir sins.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t you love such a man if you saw him\xe2\x80\x94if he were here in\r\nthis village? What a kind heart he must have! What a friend he would be\r\nto go to in trouble! How pleasant it must be to be taught by him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, dear friends, who _was_ this man? Was he only a good man\xe2\x80\x94a very\r\ngood man, and no more\xe2\x80\x94like our dear Mr. Wesley, who has been taken from\r\nus?... He was the Son of God\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98in the image of the Father,\xe2\x80\x99 the Bible\r\nsays; that means, just like God, who is the beginning and end of all\r\nthings\xe2\x80\x94the God we want to know about. So then, all the love that Jesus\r\nshowed to the poor is the same love that God has for us. We can\r\nunderstand what Jesus felt, because he came in a body like ours and\r\nspoke words such as we speak to each other. We were afraid to think\r\nwhat God was before\xe2\x80\x94the God who made the world and the sky and the\r\nthunder and lightning. We could never see him; we could only see the\r\nthings he had made; and some of these things was very terrible, so as\r\nwe might well tremble when we thought of him. But our blessed Saviour\r\nhas showed us what God is in a way us poor ignorant people can\r\nunderstand; he has showed us what God\xe2\x80\x99s heart is, what are his feelings\r\ntowards us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut let us see a little more about what Jesus came on earth for.\r\nAnother time he said, \xe2\x80\x98I came to seek and to save that which was lost\xe2\x80\x99;\r\nand another time, \xe2\x80\x98I came not to call the righteous but sinners to\r\nrepentance.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe _lost!... Sinners!_... Ah, dear friends, does that mean you and\r\nme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHitherto the traveller had been chained to the spot against his will by\r\nthe charm of Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s mellow treble tones, which had a variety of\r\nmodulation like that of a fine instrument touched with the unconscious\r\nskill of musical instinct. The simple things she said seemed like\r\nnovelties, as a melody strikes us with a new feeling when we hear it\r\nsung by the pure voice of a boyish chorister; the quiet depth of\r\nconviction with which she spoke seemed in itself an evidence for the\r\ntruth of her message. He saw that she had thoroughly arrested her\r\nhearers. The villagers had pressed nearer to her, and there was no\r\nlonger anything but grave attention on all faces. She spoke slowly,\r\nthough quite fluently, often pausing after a question, or before any\r\ntransition of ideas. There was no change of attitude, no gesture; the\r\neffect of her speech was produced entirely by the inflections of her\r\nvoice, and when she came to the question, \xe2\x80\x9cWill God take care of us\r\nwhen we die?\xe2\x80\x9d she uttered it in such a tone of plaintive appeal that\r\nthe tears came into some of the hardest eyes. The stranger had ceased\r\nto doubt, as he had done at the first glance, that she could fix the\r\nattention of her rougher hearers, but still he wondered whether she\r\ncould have that power of rousing their more violent emotions, which\r\nmust surely be a necessary seal of her vocation as a Methodist\r\npreacher, until she came to the words, \xe2\x80\x9cLost!\xe2\x80\x94Sinners!\xe2\x80\x9d when there was\r\na great change in her voice and manner. She had made a long pause\r\nbefore the exclamation, and the pause seemed to be filled by agitating\r\nthoughts that showed themselves in her features. Her pale face became\r\npaler; the circles under her eyes deepened, as they did when tears\r\nhalf-gather without falling; and the mild loving eyes took an\r\nexpression of appalled pity, as if she had suddenly discerned a\r\ndestroying angel hovering over the heads of the people. Her voice\r\nbecame deep and muffled, but there was still no gesture. Nothing could\r\nbe less like the ordinary type of the Ranter than Dinah. She was not\r\npreaching as she heard others preach, but speaking directly from her\r\nown emotions and under the inspiration of her own simple faith.\r\n\r\nBut now she had entered into a new current of feeling. Her manner\r\nbecame less calm, her utterance more rapid and agitated, as she tried\r\nto bring home to the people their guilt, their wilful darkness, their\r\nstate of disobedience to God\xe2\x80\x94as she dwelt on the hatefulness of sin,\r\nthe Divine holiness, and the sufferings of the Saviour, by which a way\r\nhad been opened for their salvation. At last it seemed as if, in her\r\nyearning desire to reclaim the lost sheep, she could not be satisfied\r\nby addressing her hearers as a body. She appealed first to one and then\r\nto another, beseeching them with tears to turn to God while there was\r\nyet time; painting to them the desolation of their souls, lost in sin,\r\nfeeding on the husks of this miserable world, far away from God their\r\nFather; and then the love of the Saviour, who was waiting and watching\r\nfor their return.\r\n\r\nThere was many a responsive sigh and groan from her fellow-Methodists,\r\nbut the village mind does not easily take fire, and a little\r\nsmouldering vague anxiety that might easily die out again was the\r\nutmost effect Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s preaching had wrought in them at present. Yet no\r\none had retired, except the children and \xe2\x80\x9cold Feyther Taft,\xe2\x80\x9d who being\r\ntoo deaf to catch many words, had some time ago gone back to his\r\ninglenook. Wiry Ben was feeling very uncomfortable, and almost wishing\r\nhe had not come to hear Dinah; he thought what she said would haunt him\r\nsomehow. Yet he couldn\xe2\x80\x99t help liking to look at her and listen to her,\r\nthough he dreaded every moment that she would fix her eyes on him and\r\naddress him in particular. She had already addressed Sandy Jim, who was\r\nnow holding the baby to relieve his wife, and the big soft-hearted man\r\nhad rubbed away some tears with his fist, with a confused intention of\r\nbeing a better fellow, going less to the Holly Bush down by the\r\nStone-pits, and cleaning himself more regularly of a Sunday.\r\n\r\nIn front of Sandy Jim stood Chad\xe2\x80\x99s Bess, who had shown an unwonted\r\nquietude and fixity of attention ever since Dinah had begun to speak.\r\nNot that the matter of the discourse had arrested her at once, for she\r\nwas lost in a puzzling speculation as to what pleasure and satisfaction\r\nthere could be in life to a young woman who wore a cap like Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\nGiving up this inquiry in despair, she took to studying Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s nose,\r\neyes, mouth, and hair, and wondering whether it was better to have such\r\na sort of pale face as that, or fat red cheeks and round black eyes\r\nlike her own. But gradually the influence of the general gravity told\r\nupon her, and she became conscious of what Dinah was saying. The gentle\r\ntones, the loving persuasion, did not touch her, but when the more\r\nsevere appeals came she began to be frightened. Poor Bessy had always\r\nbeen considered a naughty girl; she was conscious of it; if it was\r\nnecessary to be very good, it was clear she must be in a bad way. She\r\ncouldn\xe2\x80\x99t find her places at church as Sally Rann could, she had often\r\nbeen tittering when she \xe2\x80\x9ccurcheyed\xe2\x80\x9d to Mr. Irwine; and these religious\r\ndeficiencies were accompanied by a corresponding slackness in the minor\r\nmorals, for Bessy belonged unquestionably to that unsoaped lazy class\r\nof feminine characters with whom you may venture to \xe2\x80\x9ceat an egg, an\r\napple, or a nut.\xe2\x80\x9d All this she was generally conscious of, and hitherto\r\nhad not been greatly ashamed of it. But now she began to feel very much\r\nas if the constable had come to take her up and carry her before the\r\njustice for some undefined offence. She had a terrified sense that God,\r\nwhom she had always thought of as very far off, was very near to her,\r\nand that Jesus was close by looking at her, though she could not see\r\nhim. For Dinah had that belief in visible manifestations of Jesus,\r\nwhich is common among the Methodists, and she communicated it\r\nirresistibly to her hearers: she made them feel that he was among them\r\nbodily, and might at any moment show himself to them in some way that\r\nwould strike anguish and penitence into their hearts.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, turning to the left, with her eyes fixed on a\r\npoint above the heads of the people. \xe2\x80\x9cSee where our blessed Lord stands\r\nand weeps and stretches out his arms towards you. Hear what he says:\r\n\xe2\x80\x98How often would I have gathered you as a hen gathereth her chickens\r\nunder her wings, and ye would not!\xe2\x80\x99... and ye would not,\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated,\r\nin a tone of pleading reproach, turning her eyes on the people again.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee the print of the nails on his dear hands and feet. It is your sins\r\nthat made them! Ah! How pale and worn he looks! He has gone through all\r\nthat great agony in the garden, when his soul was exceeding sorrowful\r\neven unto death, and the great drops of sweat fell like blood to the\r\nground. They spat upon him and buffeted him, they scourged him, they\r\nmocked him, they laid the heavy cross on his bruised shoulders. Then\r\nthey nailed him up. Ah, what pain! His lips are parched with thirst,\r\nand they mock him still in this great agony; yet with those parched\r\nlips he prays for them, \xe2\x80\x98Father, forgive them, for they know not what\r\nthey do.\xe2\x80\x99 Then a horror of great darkness fell upon him, and he felt\r\nwhat sinners feel when they are for ever shut out from God. That was\r\nthe last drop in the cup of bitterness. \xe2\x80\x98My God, my God!\xe2\x80\x99 he cries,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98why hast Thou forsaken me?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll this he bore for you! For you\xe2\x80\x94and you never think of him; for\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94and you turn your backs on him; you don\xe2\x80\x99t care what he has gone\r\nthrough for you. Yet he is not weary of toiling for you: he has risen\r\nfrom the dead, he is praying for you at the right hand of God\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Father,\r\nforgive them, for they know not what they do.\xe2\x80\x99 And he is upon this\r\nearth too; he is among us; he is there close to you now; I see his\r\nwounded body and his look of love.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere Dinah turned to Bessy Cranage, whose bonny youth and evident\r\nvanity had touched her with pity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor child! Poor child! He is beseeching you, and you don\xe2\x80\x99t listen to\r\nhim. You think of ear-rings and fine gowns and caps, and you never\r\nthink of the Saviour who died to save your precious soul. Your cheeks\r\nwill be shrivelled one day, your hair will be grey, your poor body will\r\nbe thin and tottering! Then you will begin to feel that your soul is\r\nnot saved; then you will have to stand before God dressed in your sins,\r\nin your evil tempers and vain thoughts. And Jesus, who stands ready to\r\nhelp you now, won\xe2\x80\x99t help you then; because you won\xe2\x80\x99t have him to be\r\nyour Saviour, he will be your judge. Now he looks at you with love and\r\nmercy and says, \xe2\x80\x98Come to me that you may have life\xe2\x80\x99; then he will turn\r\naway from you, and say, \xe2\x80\x98Depart from me into ever-lasting fire!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor Bessy\xe2\x80\x99s wide-open black eyes began to fill with tears, her great\r\nred cheeks and lips became quite pale, and her face was distorted like\r\na little child\xe2\x80\x99s before a burst of crying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, poor blind child!\xe2\x80\x9d Dinah went on, \xe2\x80\x9cthink if it should happen to\r\nyou as it once happened to a servant of God in the days of her vanity.\r\n_She_ thought of her lace caps and saved all her money to buy \xe2\x80\x99em; she\r\nthought nothing about how she might get a clean heart and a right\r\nspirit\xe2\x80\x94she only wanted to have better lace than other girls. And one\r\nday when she put her new cap on and looked in the glass, she saw a\r\nbleeding Face crowned with thorns. That face is looking at you\r\nnow\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94here Dinah pointed to a spot close in front of Bessy\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAh, tear off\r\nthose follies! Cast them away from you, as if they were stinging\r\nadders. They _are_ stinging you\xe2\x80\x94they are poisoning your soul\xe2\x80\x94they are\r\ndragging you down into a dark bottomless pit, where you will sink for\r\never, and for ever, and for ever, further away from light and God.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessy could bear it no longer: a great terror was upon her, and\r\nwrenching her ear-rings from her ears, she threw them down before her,\r\nsobbing aloud. Her father, Chad, frightened lest he should be \xe2\x80\x9claid\r\nhold on\xe2\x80\x9d too, this impression on the rebellious Bess striking him as\r\nnothing less than a miracle, walked hastily away and began to work at\r\nhis anvil by way of reassuring himself. \xe2\x80\x9cFolks mun ha\xe2\x80\x99 hoss-shoes,\r\npraichin\xe2\x80\x99 or no praichin\xe2\x80\x99: the divil canna lay hould o\xe2\x80\x99 me for that,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe muttered to himself.\r\n\r\nBut now Dinah began to tell of the joys that were in store for the\r\npenitent, and to describe in her simple way the divine peace and love\r\nwith which the soul of the believer is filled\xe2\x80\x94how the sense of God\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlove turns poverty into riches and satisfies the soul so that no uneasy\r\ndesire vexes it, no fear alarms it: how, at last, the very temptation\r\nto sin is extinguished, and heaven is begun upon earth, because no\r\ncloud passes between the soul and God, who is its eternal sun.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear friends,\xe2\x80\x9d she said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cbrothers and sisters, whom I love as\r\nthose for whom my Lord has died, believe me, I know what this great\r\nblessedness is; and because I know it, I want you to have it too. I am\r\npoor, like you: I have to get my living with my hands; but no lord nor\r\nlady can be so happy as me, if they haven\xe2\x80\x99t got the love of God in\r\ntheir souls. Think what it is\xe2\x80\x94not to hate anything but sin; to be full\r\nof love to every creature; to be frightened at nothing; to be sure that\r\nall things will turn to good; not to mind pain, because it is our\r\nFather\xe2\x80\x99s will; to know that nothing\xe2\x80\x94no, not if the earth was to be\r\nburnt up, or the waters come and drown us\xe2\x80\x94nothing could part us from\r\nGod who loves us, and who fills our souls with peace and joy, because\r\nwe are sure that whatever he wills is holy, just, and good.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear friends, come and take this blessedness; it is offered to you; it\r\nis the good news that Jesus came to preach to the poor. It is not like\r\nthe riches of this world, so that the more one gets the less the rest\r\ncan have. God is without end; his love is without end\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIts streams the whole creation reach,\r\n    So plenteous is the store;\r\nEnough for all, enough for each,\r\n    Enough for evermore.\r\n\r\n\r\nDinah had been speaking at least an hour, and the reddening light of\r\nthe parting day seemed to give a solemn emphasis to her closing words.\r\nThe stranger, who had been interested in the course of her sermon as if\r\nit had been the development of a drama\xe2\x80\x94for there is this sort of\r\nfascination in all sincere unpremeditated eloquence, which opens to one\r\nthe inward drama of the speaker\xe2\x80\x99s emotions\xe2\x80\x94now turned his horse aside\r\nand pursued his way, while Dinah said, \xe2\x80\x9cLet us sing a little, dear\r\nfriends\xe2\x80\x9d; and as he was still winding down the slope, the voices of the\r\nMethodists reached him, rising and falling in that strange blending of\r\nexultation and sadness which belongs to the cadence of a hymn.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter III\r\nAfter the Preaching\r\n\r\n\r\nIn less than an hour from that time, Seth Bede was walking by Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside along the hedgerow-path that skirted the pastures and green\r\ncorn-fields which lay between the village and the Hall Farm. Dinah had\r\ntaken off her little Quaker bonnet again, and was holding it in her\r\nhands that she might have a freer enjoyment of the cool evening\r\ntwilight, and Seth could see the expression of her face quite clearly\r\nas he walked by her side, timidly revolving something he wanted to say\r\nto her. It was an expression of unconscious placid gravity\xe2\x80\x94of\r\nabsorption in thoughts that had no connection with the present moment\r\nor with her own personality\xe2\x80\x94an expression that is most of all\r\ndiscouraging to a lover. Her very walk was discouraging: it had that\r\nquiet elasticity that asks for no support. Seth felt this dimly; he\r\nsaid to himself, \xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s too good and holy for any man, let alone me,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand the words he had been summoning rushed back again before they had\r\nreached his lips. But another thought gave him courage: \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s no man\r\ncould love her better and leave her freer to follow the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThey had been silent for many minutes now, since they had done talking\r\nabout Bessy Cranage; Dinah seemed almost to have forgotten Seth\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npresence, and her pace was becoming so much quicker that the sense of\r\ntheir being only a few minutes\xe2\x80\x99 walk from the yard-gates of the Hall\r\nFarm at last gave Seth courage to speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve quite made up your mind to go back to Snowfield o\xe2\x80\x99 Saturday,\r\nDinah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, quietly. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m called there. It was borne in upon my\r\nmind while I was meditating on Sunday night, as Sister Allen, who\xe2\x80\x99s in\r\na decline, is in need of me. I saw her as plain as we see that bit of\r\nthin white cloud, lifting up her poor thin hand and beckoning to me.\r\nAnd this morning when I opened the Bible for direction, the first words\r\nmy eyes fell on were, \xe2\x80\x98And after we had seen the vision, immediately we\r\nendeavoured to go into Macedonia.\xe2\x80\x99 If it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for that clear showing\r\nof the Lord\xe2\x80\x99s will, I should be loath to go, for my heart yearns over\r\nmy aunt and her little ones, and that poor wandering lamb Hetty Sorrel.\r\nI\xe2\x80\x99ve been much drawn out in prayer for her of late, and I look on it as\r\na token that there may be mercy in store for her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod grant it,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth. \xe2\x80\x9cFor I doubt Adam\xe2\x80\x99s heart is so set on her,\r\nhe\xe2\x80\x99ll never turn to anybody else; and yet it \xe2\x80\x99ud go to my heart if he\r\nwas to marry her, for I canna think as she\xe2\x80\x99d make him happy. It\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\ndeep mystery\xe2\x80\x94the way the heart of man turns to one woman out of all the\r\nrest he\xe2\x80\x99s seen i\xe2\x80\x99 the world, and makes it easier for him to work seven\r\nyear for _her_, like Jacob did for Rachel, sooner than have any other\r\nwoman for th\xe2\x80\x99 asking. I often think of them words, \xe2\x80\x98And Jacob served\r\nseven years for Rachel; and they seemed to him but a few days for the\r\nlove he had to her.\xe2\x80\x99 I know those words \xe2\x80\x99ud come true with me, Dinah,\r\nif so be you\xe2\x80\x99d give me hope as I might win you after seven years was\r\nover. I know you think a husband \xe2\x80\x99ud be taking up too much o\xe2\x80\x99 your\r\nthoughts, because St. Paul says, \xe2\x80\x98She that\xe2\x80\x99s married careth for the\r\nthings of the world how she may please her husband\xe2\x80\x99; and may happen\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99ll think me overbold to speak to you about it again, after what you\r\ntold me o\xe2\x80\x99 your mind last Saturday. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking it over\r\nagain by night and by day, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve prayed not to be blinded by my own\r\ndesires, to think what\xe2\x80\x99s only good for me must be good for you too. And\r\nit seems to me there\xe2\x80\x99s more texts for your marrying than ever you can\r\nfind against it. For St. Paul says as plain as can be in another place,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98I will that the younger women marry, bear children, guide the house,\r\ngive none occasion to the adversary to speak reproachfully\xe2\x80\x99; and then\r\n\xe2\x80\x98two are better than one\xe2\x80\x99; and that holds good with marriage as well as\r\nwith other things. For we should be o\xe2\x80\x99 one heart and o\xe2\x80\x99 one mind,\r\nDinah. We both serve the same Master, and are striving after the same\r\ngifts; and I\xe2\x80\x99d never be the husband to make a claim on you as could\r\ninterfere with your doing the work God has fitted you for. I\xe2\x80\x99d make a\r\nshift, and fend indoor and out, to give you more liberty\xe2\x80\x94more than you\r\ncan have now, for you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to get your own living now, and I\xe2\x80\x99m strong\r\nenough to work for us both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen Seth had once begun to urge his suit, he went on earnestly and\r\nalmost hurriedly, lest Dinah should speak some decisive word before he\r\nhad poured forth all the arguments he had prepared. His cheeks became\r\nflushed as he went on, his mild grey eyes filled with tears, and his\r\nvoice trembled as he spoke the last sentence.
