So Adam got on his\r\nhorse again and rode to the town, putting up at the old inn and taking\r\na hasty dinner there in the company of the too chatty landlord, from\r\nwhose friendly questions and reminiscences he was glad to escape as\r\nsoon as possible and set out towards Sloman\xe2\x80\x99s End. With all his haste\r\nit was nearly four o\xe2\x80\x99clock before he could set off, and he thought that\r\nas Dinah had gone so early, she would perhaps already be near\r\nreturning. The little, grey, desolate-looking hamlet, unscreened by\r\nsheltering trees, lay in sight long before he reached it, and as he\r\ncame near he could hear the sound of voices singing a hymn. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x99s the last hymn before they come away,\xe2\x80\x9d Adam thought. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll walk\r\nback a bit and turn again to meet her, farther off the village.\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nwalked back till he got nearly to the top of the hill again, and seated\r\nhimself on a loose stone, against the low wall, to watch till he should\r\nsee the little black figure leaving the hamlet and winding up the hill.\r\nHe chose this spot, almost at the top of the hill, because it was away\r\nfrom all eyes\xe2\x80\x94no house, no cattle, not even a nibbling sheep near\xe2\x80\x94no\r\npresence but the still lights and shadows and the great embracing sky.\r\n\r\nShe was much longer coming than he expected. He waited an hour at least\r\nwatching for her and thinking of her, while the afternoon shadows\r\nlengthened and the light grew softer. At last he saw the little black\r\nfigure coming from between the grey houses and gradually approaching\r\nthe foot of the hill. Slowly, Adam thought, but Dinah was really\r\nwalking at her usual pace, with a light quiet step. Now she was\r\nbeginning to wind along the path up the hill, but Adam would not move\r\nyet; he would not meet her too soon; he had set his heart on meeting\r\nher in this assured loneliness. And now he began to fear lest he should\r\nstartle her too much. \xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d he thought, \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s not one to be\r\noverstartled; she\xe2\x80\x99s always so calm and quiet, as if she was prepared\r\nfor anything.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat was she thinking of as she wound up the hill? Perhaps she had\r\nfound complete repose without him, and had ceased to feel any need of\r\nhis love. On the verge of a decision we all tremble: hope pauses with\r\nfluttering wings.\r\n\r\nBut now at last she was very near, and Adam rose from the stone wall.\r\nIt happened that just as he walked forward, Dinah had paused and turned\r\nround to look back at the village\xe2\x80\x94who does not pause and look back in\r\nmounting a hill? Adam was glad, for, with the fine instinct of a lover,\r\nhe felt that it would be best for her to hear his voice before she saw\r\nhim. He came within three paces of her and then said, \xe2\x80\x9cDinah!\xe2\x80\x9d She\r\nstarted without looking round, as if she connected the sound with no\r\nplace. \xe2\x80\x9cDinah!\xe2\x80\x9d Adam said again. He knew quite well what was in her\r\nmind. She was so accustomed to think of impressions as purely spiritual\r\nmonitions that she looked for no material visible accompaniment of the\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\nBut this second time she looked round. What a look of yearning love it\r\nwas that the mild grey eyes turned on the strong dark-eyed man! She did\r\nnot start again at the sight of him; she said nothing, but moved\r\ntowards him so that his arm could clasp her round.\r\n\r\nAnd they walked on so in silence, while the warm tears fell. Adam was\r\ncontent, and said nothing. It was Dinah who spoke first.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAdam,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cit is the Divine Will. My soul is so knit to yours\r\nthat it is but a divided life I live without you. And this moment, now\r\nyou are with me, and I feel that our hearts are filled with the same\r\nlove. I have a fulness of strength to bear and do our heavenly Father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nWill that I had lost before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAdam paused and looked into her sincere eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen we\xe2\x80\x99ll never part any more, Dinah, till death parts us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd they kissed each other with a deep joy.\r\n\r\nWhat greater thing is there for two human souls than to feel that they\r\nare joined for life\xe2\x80\x94to strengthen each other in all labour, to rest on\r\neach other in all sorrow, to minister to each other in all pain, to be\r\none with each other in silent unspeakable memories at the moment of the\r\nlast parting?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nChapter LV\r\nMarriage Bells\r\n\r\n\r\nIn little more than a month after that meeting on the hill\xe2\x80\x94on a rimy\r\nmorning in departing November\xe2\x80\x94Adam and Dinah were married.\r\n\r\nIt was an event much thought of in the village. All Mr. Burge\xe2\x80\x99s men had\r\na holiday, and all Mr. Poyser\xe2\x80\x99s, and most of those who had a holiday\r\nappeared in their best clothes at the wedding. I think there was hardly\r\nan inhabitant of Hayslope specially mentioned in this history and still\r\nresident in the parish on this November morning who was not either in\r\nchurch to see Adam and Dinah married, or near the church door to greet\r\nthem as they came forth. Mrs. Irwine and her daughters were waiting at\r\nthe churchyard gates in their carriage (for they had a carriage now) to\r\nshake hands with the bride and bridegroom and wish them well; and in\r\nthe absence of Miss Lydia Donnithorne at Bath, Mrs. Best, Mr. Mills,\r\nand Mr. Craig had felt it incumbent on them to represent \xe2\x80\x9cthe family\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nat the Chase on the occasion. The churchyard walk was quite lined with\r\nfamiliar faces, many of them faces that had first looked at Dinah when\r\nshe preached on the Green. And no wonder they showed this eager\r\ninterest on her marriage morning, for nothing like Dinah and the\r\nhistory which had brought her and Adam Bede together had been known at\r\nHayslope within the memory of man.\r\n\r\nBessy Cranage, in her neatest cap and frock, was crying, though she did\r\nnot exactly know why; for, as her cousin Wiry Ben, who stood near her,\r\njudiciously suggested, Dinah was not going away, and if Bessy was in\r\nlow spirits, the best thing for her to do was to follow Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s example\r\nand marry an honest fellow who was ready to have her. Next to Bessy,\r\njust within the church door, there were the Poyser children, peeping\r\nround the corner of the pews to get a sight of the mysterious ceremony;\r\nTotty\xe2\x80\x99s face wearing an unusual air of anxiety at the idea of seeing\r\ncousin Dinah come back looking rather old, for in Totty\xe2\x80\x99s experience no\r\nmarried people were young.\r\n\r\nI envy them all the sight they had when the marriage was fairly ended\r\nand Adam led Dinah out of church. She was not in black this morning,\r\nfor her Aunt Poyser would by no means allow such a risk of incurring\r\nbad luck, and had herself made a present of the wedding dress, made all\r\nof grey, though in the usual Quaker form, for on this point Dinah could\r\nnot give way. So the lily face looked out with sweet gravity from under\r\na grey Quaker bonnet, neither smiling nor blushing, but with lips\r\ntrembling a little under the weight of solemn feelings. Adam, as he\r\npressed her arm to his side, walked with his old erectness and his head\r\nthrown rather backward as if to face all the world better. But it was\r\nnot because he was particularly proud this morning, as is the wont of\r\nbridegrooms, for his happiness was of a kind that had little reference\r\nto men\xe2\x80\x99s opinion of it. There was a tinge of sadness in his deep joy;\r\nDinah knew it, and did not feel aggrieved.\r\n\r\nThere were three other couples, following the bride and bridegroom:\r\nfirst, Martin Poyser, looking as cheery as a bright fire on this rimy\r\nmorning, led quiet Mary Burge, the bridesmaid; then came Seth serenely\r\nhappy, with Mrs. Poyser on his arm; and last of all Bartle Massey, with\r\nLisbeth\xe2\x80\x94Lisbeth in a new gown and bonnet, too busy with her pride in\r\nher son and her delight in possessing the one daughter she had desired\r\nto devise a single pretext for complaint.\r\n\r\nBartle Massey had consented to attend the wedding at Adam\xe2\x80\x99s earnest\r\nrequest, under protest against marriage in general and the marriage of\r\na sensible man in particular. Nevertheless, Mr. Poyser had a joke\r\nagainst him after the wedding dinner, to the effect that in the vestry\r\nhe had given the bride one more kiss than was necessary.\r\n\r\nBehind this last couple came Mr. Irwine, glad at heart over this good\r\nmorning\xe2\x80\x99s work of joining Adam and Dinah. For he had seen Adam in the\r\nworst moments of his sorrow; and what better harvest from that painful\r\nseed-time could there be than this? The love that had brought hope and\r\ncomfort in the hour of despair, the love that had found its way to the\r\ndark prison cell and to poor Hetty\xe2\x80\x99s darker soul\xe2\x80\x94this strong gentle\r\nlove was to be Adam\xe2\x80\x99s companion and helper till death.\r\n\r\nThere was much shaking of hands mingled with \xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nother good wishes to the four couples, at the churchyard gate, Mr.\r\nPoyser answering for the rest with unwonted vivacity of tongue, for he\r\nhad all the appropriate wedding-day jokes at his command. And the\r\nwomen, he observed, could never do anything but put finger in eye at a\r\nwedding. Even Mrs. Poyser could not trust herself to speak as the\r\nneighbours shook hands with her, and Lisbeth began to cry in the face\r\nof the very first person who told her she was getting young again.\r\n\r\nMr. Joshua Rann, having a slight touch of rheumatism, did not join in\r\nthe ringing of the bells this morning, and, looking on with some\r\ncontempt at these informal greetings which required no official\r\nco-operation from the clerk, began to hum in his musical bass, \xe2\x80\x9cOh what\r\na joyful thing it is,\xe2\x80\x9d by way of preluding a little to the effect he\r\nintended to produce in the wedding psalm next Sunday.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a bit of good news to cheer Arthur,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Irwine to his\r\nmother, as they drove off. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall write to him the first thing when\r\nwe get home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEpilogue\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is near the end of June, in 1807. The workshops have been shut up\r\nhalf an hour or more in Adam Bede\xe2\x80\x99s timber-yard, which used to be\r\nJonathan Burge\xe2\x80\x99s, and the mellow evening light is falling on the\r\npleasant house with the buff walls and the soft grey thatch, very much\r\nas it did when we saw Adam bringing in the keys on that June evening\r\nnine years ago.\r\n\r\nThere is a figure we know well, just come out of the house, and shading\r\nher eyes with her hands as she looks for something in the distance, for\r\nthe rays that fall on her white borderless cap and her pale auburn hair\r\nare very dazzling. But now she turns away from the sunlight and looks\r\ntowards the door.\r\n\r\nWe can see the sweet pale face quite well now: it is scarcely at all\r\naltered\xe2\x80\x94only a little fuller, to correspond to her more matronly\r\nfigure, which still seems light and active enough in the plain black\r\ndress.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see him, Seth,\xe2\x80\x9d Dinah said, as she looked into the house. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us go\r\nand meet him. Come, Lisbeth, come with Mother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe last call was answered immediately by a small fair creature with\r\npale auburn hair and grey eyes, little more than four years old, who\r\nran out silently and put her hand into her mother\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Uncle Seth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, aye, we\xe2\x80\x99re coming,\xe2\x80\x9d Seth answered from within, and presently\r\nappeared stooping under the doorway, being taller than usual by the\r\nblack head of a sturdy two-year-old nephew, who had caused some delay\r\nby demanding to be carried on uncle\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetter take him on thy arm, Seth,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, looking fondly at the\r\nstout black-eyed fellow. \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s troublesome to thee so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, nay: Addy likes a ride on my shoulder. I can carry him so for a\r\nbit.\xe2\x80\x9d A kindness which young Addy acknowledged by drumming his heels\r\nwith promising force against Uncle Seth\xe2\x80\x99s chest. But to walk by Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nside, and be tyrannized over by Dinah\xe2\x80\x99s and Adam\xe2\x80\x99s children, was Uncle\r\nSeth\xe2\x80\x99s earthly happiness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere didst see him?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Seth, as they walked on into the adjoining\r\nfield. \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t catch sight of him anywhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBetween the hedges by the roadside,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah. \xe2\x80\x9cI saw his hat and\r\nhis shoulder. There he is again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTrust thee for catching sight of him if he\xe2\x80\x99s anywhere to be seen,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid Seth, smiling. \xe2\x80\x9cThee\xe2\x80\x99t like poor mother used to be. She was always\r\non the look out for Adam, and could see him sooner than other folks,\r\nfor all her eyes got dim.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s been longer than he expected,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, taking Arthur\xe2\x80\x99s watch\r\nfrom a small side pocket and looking at it; \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s nigh upon seven now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye, they\xe2\x80\x99d have a deal to say to one another,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, \xe2\x80\x9cand the\r\nmeeting \xe2\x80\x99ud touch \xe2\x80\x99em both pretty closish. Why, it\xe2\x80\x99s getting on towards\r\neight years since they parted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah, \xe2\x80\x9cAdam was greatly moved this morning at the thought\r\nof the change he should see in the poor young man, from the sickness he\r\nhas undergone, as well as the years which have changed us all. And the\r\ndeath of the poor wanderer, when she was coming back to us, has been\r\nsorrow upon sorrow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSee, Addy,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, lowering the young one to his arm now and\r\npointing, \xe2\x80\x9cthere\xe2\x80\x99s Father coming\xe2\x80\x94at the far stile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDinah hastened her steps, and little Lisbeth ran on at her utmost speed\r\ntill she clasped her father\xe2\x80\x99s leg. Adam patted her head and lifted her\r\nup to kiss her, but Dinah could see the marks of agitation on his face\r\nas she approached him, and he put her arm within his in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, youngster, must I take you?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, trying to smile, when Addy\r\nstretched out his arms\xe2\x80\x94ready, with the usual baseness of infancy, to\r\ngive up his Uncle Seth at once, now there was some rarer patronage at\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s cut me a good deal, Dinah,\xe2\x80\x9d Adam said at last, when they were\r\nwalking on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidst find him greatly altered?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, he\xe2\x80\x99s altered and yet not altered. I should ha\xe2\x80\x99 known him\r\nanywhere. But his colour\xe2\x80\x99s changed, and he looks sadly. However, the\r\ndoctors say he\xe2\x80\x99ll soon be set right in his own country air. He\xe2\x80\x99s all\r\nsound in th\xe2\x80\x99 inside; it\xe2\x80\x99s only the fever shattered him so. But he\r\nspeaks just the same, and smiles at me just as he did when he was a\r\nlad. It\xe2\x80\x99s wonderful how he\xe2\x80\x99s always had just the same sort o\xe2\x80\x99 look when\r\nhe smiles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve never seen him smile, poor young man,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut thee _wilt_ see him smile, to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam. \xe2\x80\x9cHe asked after\r\nthee the first thing when he began to come round, and we could talk to\r\none another. \xe2\x80\x98I hope she isn\xe2\x80\x99t altered,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98I remember her face\r\nso well.\xe2\x80\x99 I told him \xe2\x80\x98no,\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d Adam continued, looking fondly at the eyes\r\nthat were turned towards his, \xe2\x80\x9conly a bit plumper, as thee\xe2\x80\x99dst a right\r\nto be after seven year. \xe2\x80\x98I may come and see her to-morrow, mayn\xe2\x80\x99t I?\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhe said; \xe2\x80\x98I long to tell her how I\xe2\x80\x99ve thought of her all these years.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDidst tell him I\xe2\x80\x99d always used the watch?\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye; and we talked a deal about thee, for he says he never saw a woman\r\na bit like thee. \xe2\x80\x98I shall turn Methodist some day,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98when she\r\npreaches out of doors, and go to hear her.\xe2\x80\x99 And I said, \xe2\x80\x98Nay, sir, you\r\ncan\xe2\x80\x99t do that, for Conference has forbid the women preaching, and she\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngiven it up, all but talking to the people a bit in their houses.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh,\xe2\x80\x9d said Seth, who could not repress a comment on this point, \xe2\x80\x9cand a\r\nsore pity it was o\xe2\x80\x99 Conference; and if Dinah had seen as I did, we\xe2\x80\x99d\r\nha\xe2\x80\x99 left the Wesleyans and joined a body that \xe2\x80\x99ud put no bonds on\r\nChristian liberty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, lad, nay,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam, \xe2\x80\x9cshe was right and thee wast wrong. There\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nno rules so wise but what it\xe2\x80\x99s a pity for somebody or other. Most o\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthe women do more harm nor good with their preaching\xe2\x80\x94they\xe2\x80\x99ve not got\r\nDinah\xe2\x80\x99s gift nor her sperrit\xe2\x80\x94and she\xe2\x80\x99s seen that, and she thought it\r\nright to set th\xe2\x80\x99 example o\xe2\x80\x99 submitting, for she\xe2\x80\x99s not held from other\r\nsorts o\xe2\x80\x99 teaching. And I agree with her, and approve o\xe2\x80\x99 what she did.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSeth was silent. This was a standing subject of difference rarely\r\nalluded to, and Dinah, wishing to quit it at once, said, \xe2\x80\x9cDidst\r\nremember, Adam, to speak to Colonel Donnithorne the words my uncle and\r\naunt entrusted to thee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, and he\xe2\x80\x99s going to the Hall Farm with Mr. Irwine the day after\r\nto-morrow. Mr. Irwine came in while we were talking about it, and he\r\nwould have it as the Colonel must see nobody but thee to-morrow. He\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94and he\xe2\x80\x99s in the right of it\xe2\x80\x94as it\xe2\x80\x99ll be bad for him t\xe2\x80\x99 have his\r\nfeelings stirred with seeing many people one after another. \xe2\x80\x98We must\r\nget you strong and hearty,\xe2\x80\x99 he said, \xe2\x80\x98that\xe2\x80\x99s the first thing to be done\r\nArthur, and then you shall have your own way. But I shall keep you\r\nunder your old tutor\xe2\x80\x99s thumb till then.\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Irwine\xe2\x80\x99s fine and joyful\r\nat having him home again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAdam was silent a little while, and then said, \xe2\x80\x9cIt was very cutting\r\nwhen we first saw one another. He\xe2\x80\x99d never heard about poor Hetty till\r\nMr. Irwine met him in London, for the letters missed him on his\r\njourney. The first thing he said to me, when we\xe2\x80\x99d got hold o\xe2\x80\x99 one\r\nanother\xe2\x80\x99s hands was, \xe2\x80\x98I could never do anything for her, Adam\xe2\x80\x94she lived\r\nlong enough for all the suffering\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99d thought so of the time when I\r\nmight do something for her. But you told me the truth when you said to\r\nme once, \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s a sort of wrong that can never be made up for.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, there\xe2\x80\x99s Mr. and Mrs. Poyser coming in at the yard gate,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nSeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo there is,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dinah. \xe2\x80\x9cRun, Lisbeth, run to meet Aunt Poyser. Come\r\nin, Adam, and rest; it has been a hard day for thee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n*** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK ADAM BEDE ***\r\n\r\nUpdated editions will replace the previous one--the old editions will\r\nbe renamed.\r\n\r\nCreating the works from print editions not protected by U.S. copyright\r\nlaw means that no one owns a United States copyright in these works,\r\nso the Foundation (and you!) can copy and distribute it in the\r\nUnited States without permission and without paying copyright\r\nroyalties.
